CHRONPROSE.BIRTHPOSITION:
MA was born in
Ottawa, Ontario
, the second of three children.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was born into a white, urban, middle-class Canadian family whose second environment, the northern wilderness, became deeply familiar to her from long summers in the bush where her father did his research.
Her mother was born Margaret Killam, a member of a Nova Scotia family which acquired prominence as merchants, politicians, financiers, and latterly philanthropists.
Her father, Dr Carl Edmund Atwood, was an academic entomologist.

MA spent her childhood in
Ottawa
,
Sault Ste Marie
, and
Toronto
, with summers in the bush area north of
Temiscaming
.
22

Margaret's earliest education was at home—from her mother, and from the major educational experience of her wilderness summers. She later enumerated the pop-cultural forms of her childhood as the movies, radio, the funny papers and comic books.
31

She attended elementary school, and then from 1952
Leaside High School in
Toronto
, both in the Protestant public school system which then operated in Canada alongside a Catholic one. She and her schoolmates got prayers and
Bible readings every day, memorized psalms and other biblical passages, and took the occasional Religious Knowledge course. The
English Literature curriculum was resolutely British:
Shakespeare , English Romantic and Victorian poets, and novels by
George Eliot and
Thomas Hardy .
9 From 1957 she attended
Victoria College ,
University of Toronto . Canadian publishing and the arts in Canada, broadly considered, had not yet recovered from the second world war. There were no cheap reprints of new Canadian books, and authors like Margaret Laurence, Mavis Gallant, and Mordecai Richler were living abroad.
33 At university MA first became aware of Canadian literature as a subject of study and a source of pleasure, a discovery which she felt she owed to two of her teachers in particular,
Northrop Frye and
Jay Macpherson . For her BA in English (awarded in 1961) she studied the canon from Anglo-Saxon literature to
T. S. Eliot ; in her final year she discovered
Sheila Watson and
Marie-Claire Blais .
36-7 She spent the year after her graduation studying Victorian literature at
Radcliffe College ,
Harvard (then an all-female institution), and then began on doctoral studies at Toronto. She broke off her doctorate in order to work, then resumed it at Harvard in 1965, where she held a Woodrow Wilson Fellowship. The new subject of her research (not completed) was the English gothic novel.

Back in
Toronto
between periods of study, she took a job in 1963 with a market research company, and then taught at the
University of British Columbia , 1964-5.
After this she taught briefly at
Sir George Williams University in
Montreal
, the
University of Alberta in
Edmonton
, and
York University ,
Toronto
. She was Writer in Residence at the
University of Toronto in 1972-3, and has since held several other Writer in Residence positions in the
USA and one at
Macquarie University ,
Australia .
251

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
MA was married in
Boston
to James Polk, whom she met while she was a graduate student at Harvard. They separated in summer 1972.

P.LIVESWITH: In 1972 MA formed a relationship with novelist Graeme Gibson, with whom she lives.

P.CHILDREN:
They have one daughter, born on 17 May 1976.
251

SHORTPROSE.P:
MA has been a lifelong Torontonian, but has lived in widely separated places:
British Columbia
,
Alberta
(1968-70), the
USA ,
Australia , and (1970-1) in Europe—
London , England ,
France , and
Italy .

In winter 1983 Atwood and Gibson spent six months in England. She mentions both a cobblestone ex-fisherman's cottage with cold stone floors and a rectory at
Blakeney in Norfolk
, reputedly haunted by nuns. She was engaged in futile struggle with the complicated time layers of a never-finished historical fiction, finding consolation in the Tudor novels of Jean Plaidy. She came home to abandon her project and write The Handmaid's Tale.

Apart from these sojourns, and a six-year period living with Gibson and their baby daughter on a farm near
Alliston, Ontario
, MA has lived in
Toronto
.

MA has spoken at length about the literary life in Toronto in the 1960s and 70s: improvisational, inventive, and far from top-heavy with a sense of [its] own importance.
20 During 1971-3 MA was editor of Anansi Press in
Toronto
, and she later served on its board.
She was also one of the organizers and impresarios of the All-Star Eclectic Typewriter Revue, a fundraising entertainment for the recently-formed Writers' Union of Canada on 9 May 1974 (or possibly on this day a year or two later) at which writers and reviewers performed, and Atwood herself took part in dance routines on snowshoes and in kilts.
20-5 The revue, she says, brought together Canadian authors of all ages and regions, working as a team and making idiots of themselves for a common cause.
30

Later, in 1982-3, MA was President of the Writers' Union of Canada. She was President of the Canadian branch of PEN International in 1984-6. She became a Vice-President of Pen International on 11 July 2007, joining other such distinguished writers as Nadine Gordimer and Toni Morrison.

In middle age MA has taken an increasingly prominent role in shaping opinion on urgent questions confronting Canadians and others living with the new global economy and a single superpower world. In articles, lectures, and interviews she has made her influence felt on women's issues and on issues of environment, nationalism, governance, peace and war, literacy, and human rights (especially prisoners' rights, especially through PEN). She is an omni-present cultural commentator. She has taken part in an annual two-week summer camp run by Somebody's Daughter, a literacy project for Inuit women in the Canadian Arctic.

She is also a pioneer (among writers) in the uses of social media, of new hybrid genres, and of the web in general. In 2012 she launched a web space entitled Fanado (http://fanado.com) designed to facilitate online contact between artists and creators of all kinds and their admirers, consumers, or fans, particularly through virtual meet-and-greet sessions and remote signatures. As an example of its work, MA remote-signed a portrait of her painted other images by Oksana Zhelisko, an artist in
Edmonton, Alberta
. The artist, delighted at virtually meeting her model, put the signed portrait up for sale on eBay to raise money for Fanado.
8 September 2015 In early summer 2016 she attended a major event hosted in
San Diego
by Comic-Con International, an organization that brings together enthusiasts for old-style comic books and new-style graphic fiction.
